titleStmt.title: The devils conquest, or, a Wish obtained: Shewing how one late of Barnsby-Street ... carried home some work to her mistris ... who asked her how much shee [sic] owed her for; the maid answered eight pounds; her mistris said 'twas but six ... the maid began to swear and curse, and wisht the Devil fetch her, if there was no eight pounds owing her ... one came and throwed her down ... and suddenly he vanished away ... which caused them to say, it was the Devil ... at midnight she heard a voice ... she swore she would come, and being got out of the bed, fell down upon her face ... her body moving in a most terrible manner ... her mistris was sent for, who freely forgave her, and wisht God might forgive her too ... her body was found as black as pitch all over; and all this was for no more than the value of eleven pence / ...written for a warning to all, to avoid the like course. The tune is, Summer Time.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 1 1-bit group-IV TIFF page image.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from: (Early English Books Online ; image set 174364)
Images scanned from microfilm: (Early English Books, 1641-1700 ; 2686:12)

titleStmt.title: The devils conquest, or, a Wish obtained: Shewing how one late of Barnsby-Street ... carried home some work to her mistris ... who asked her how much shee [sic] owed her for; the maid answered eight pounds; her mistris said 'twas but six ... the maid began to swear and curse, and wisht the Devil fetch her, if there was no eight pounds owing her ... one came and throwed her down ... and suddenly he vanished away ... which caused them to say, it was the Devil ... at midnight she heard a voice ... she swore she would come, and being got out of the bed, fell down upon her face ... her body moving in a most terrible manner ... her mistris was sent for, who freely forgave her, and wisht God might forgive her too ... her body was found as black as pitch all over; and all this was for no more than the value of eleven pence / ...written for a warning to all, to avoid the like course. The tune is, Summer Time.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for S. Tyus, on London-Bridge. With privilege.,

notesStmt.note: Date of publication taken from Wing (2nd ed.)
Reproduction of original in: University of Glasgow Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2008-06 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2008-07 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

argument.p: Shewing how one lately of Barnsby-≈øtreet, in Leg-Ally, in St. Olaves Pari≈øh, Southwark, one that Carded Wooll for Stockings, carried home ≈øome work to her Mi≈øtris, living upon Hor≈øly-Down, who asked her how much ≈øhee owed her for; the Maid an≈øwered eight pounds; her Mi≈øtris ≈øaid 'twas but ≈øix whereupon the Maid began to Swear and Cur≈øe, and wi≈øht the Devil fetch her, if there was not eight pounds owing for; the Mi≈øtris loving quietne≈øs, paid her for eight pound: the Maid, with two of her Companions, walking over Hor≈øly-Down, ≈øhe having a Childe in her arms, one came and throwed her down, and pre≈øently took her up again, which cau≈øed her to ≈øay, Thou Rogue, do≈øt thou fling me down and take me up again, and ≈øuddainly he vani≈øhed away, neither ≈øhe, nor the two women with her, could di≈øcern which way he went, which cau≈øed them to ≈øay, It was the Devil, which for all this, nothing terrified the Maid, who went boldly home, and to bed, and the two Women with her; at midnight ≈øhe heard a voice, which called her by her name very often; ≈øhe an≈øwered, I come, I come; but the voice ≈øtill continuing, ≈øhe ≈øwore ≈øhe would come, and being got out of the Bed, fell down upon her face, and was taken ≈øpeechle≈øs, yet her body moving in mo≈øt terrible manner, manife≈øting her inward pangs; her Mi≈øtris was ≈øent for, who freely forgave her, and wi≈øht God might forgive her too, and then ≈øhee departed, and her body was found as black as pitch all over; and all this was for no more than the value of eleven pence, which was done on the 6th. of this in≈øtant May, 1665. and was written for a warning to all, to avoid the like cour≈øe.

lg.l: ATtend good Chri≈øtian people all
to what here I do mean to write,
You Mu≈øes nine, to you I call,
help me the≈øe ver≈øes to indite.
A ≈øtory true I ≈øhall relate,
I wi≈øh it may a warning be,
That all may now avoid that fate,
and ≈øhun that cruel de≈øtiny.
Full ≈øore & dreadful judgements we
have often heard and ≈ø√©en abroad,
The righteous God, he doth decree,
as we have it upon Record.
Many a time we do provoke,
yet ≈øtill his mercy doth indure,
But at the la≈øt h√©e'l give a ≈øtroak,
which art of man can never cure.
Examples many we have had
in former and in latter years,
But ≈øure you ne'r heard one more ≈øad
then this, therefore attend to hear.
In Barnsby-≈øtreet of late there dwelt
one Margery Perry called by name,
With whom it ≈ø√©ems the Devil dealt,
and played his ≈øubtil cunning game.
In carding wool ≈øhe imploy'd her ≈øelf,
a lively hood for to obtain,
But Satan that old ≈øubtil Elf,
tells her 'tis not ≈øufficient gain.
TO ≈øwear and cur≈øe ≈øhe was inclin'd
a Vice too common in this Land,
In this the Devil with her was joyn'd,
as you ≈øhall ≈øhortly under≈øtand.
She carried home ≈øome work one day
unto her Work-Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes home,
Who asked how much ≈øhe had to pay
for all the wool that ≈øhe did combe.
Saith ≈øhe, you owe me for eight pounds
nay, ≈øaith the Mi≈øtris, it is but ≈øir,
But now ≈øhe goes beyond her bounds,
to ≈øwear and cur≈øe ≈øhe doth not ≈øtick.
This cau≈øed ≈øome conte≈øt to ari≈øe
betw√©en them both, for a ≈øhort ≈øpace,
The Devils flame in her brea≈øt fries,
O woman! what made th√©e ≈øo ba≈øe?
She wi≈øht the Devil fetch her ≈øtrait,
if that ≈øhe had not done eight pounds;
Ah woman! caught with ≈øuch a bait,
that came not all to half a crown.
Her Mi≈øtris paid her, away ≈øhe hies,
& with her Comrades walk ye ≈øtr√©ets,
≈øhe little thought how con≈øcience cries
but now at la≈øt the Devil m√©ets.
On Hor≈øly-down ≈øhe down was thrown
and pre≈øently caught up again,
Alas ≈øhe is ≈øo hard hearted grown,
≈øhe can't perceive her inward ≈øtain.
Tho≈øe women with her were amazed,
becau≈øe he vani≈øhed quite away
That took her up, although they gazed,
no more of him they ≈øaw that day.
Then home ≈øhe hies with her con≈øorts,
to bed ≈øhe goes and thinks all well,
But vengeance will at length ari≈øe,
& death will come with pa≈ø≈øing bell.
Oh little did ≈øhe think, but ≈øhe
≈øhould ri≈øe again as ≈øhe was wont,
Iudgement mu≈øt come by Gods decr√©e,
he will not alwaies bear the affront.
At midnight then ≈øhe heard a voice,
which frequently called her by name,
Surely ≈øhe could not then rejoyce,
knowing her guilt de≈øerved blame.
She an≈øwered ≈øtraight, I come, I come,
and pre≈øently begins to ≈øwear,
The Devil h√©e'l not ≈øtay too long,
but takes her in her chamber there.
They took her up from off the boards,
whereon ye Devil her down did throw
She ≈øp√©echle≈øs was, no breath affords,
which made ye womens hearts to glow
Then for her Mi≈øtris they did ≈øend,
who came immediately to ≈ø√©e
That, which almo≈øt her heart did rend,
a ≈øpectacle of mi≈øery.
Some that were pre≈øent there did ≈øay,
forgive her though ≈øhe did for≈øwear,
I and God forgive her too I pray,
and ≈øo ≈øhe died whil≈øt ≈øhe was there.
They ≈øtript her naked being dead,
and found her body black as pitch,
The helli≈øh fiend her prepared,
according to her cur≈øed wi≈øh.
Oh that a warning this might be
to all, that the≈øe few lines do read,
Here plainly we may learn and ≈ø√©e
and not ≈øuch wicked paths to tread.
Wi≈øh for true riches and true grace,
and labour for it earne≈øtly,
The Devil he will come apace,
wi≈øh not for him, ≈øuch cour≈øes fly.
And now lets ≈øtudy to amend,
and fr√©e our ≈øelves from ≈ølavery,
That all our lives may have good end,
and full a≈ø≈øurance when we dye.
So to conclude remember ≈øtill,
Swearing and Cur≈øing ends in woe,
If you let the Devil have his will,
h√©e'l prove the wor≈øt & greate≈øt foe.

div.p: London Printed for S. Tyus, on London-Bridge. With privilege. Finis.
